comments.commentBody: I don't understand wires.  I untangled them when taking the system apart and laid them all out separately.  When it came time to put the system together again, they were retangled.  After I untangled them and put the system together and tried to plug everything in, they were tangled yet again.  I don't know how they do that.  I think they took lessons from Christmas tree lights.

It could be worse.

I spent most of the day moving furniture arund. That involved dismantling and then remantling my whole computer system, plus the TV and its accessories, plus even the phone and answering machine. After what seemed like hours untangling wires and trying to figure out what went into what and finding them tangled up again, only to find I had no sound on my computer, I was really tired and frustrated. I finally got the sound back, and cobbled together a little dinner, then made myself a little drinkie to accompany my Saturday night's relaxation with the Sunday puzzle.

Imagine my joy when Patrick Berry's name appeared on the screen.

And he didn't disappoint, not really. While I too prefer my Sunday puzzles to be really difficult, after the day I'd had not so much. And this one was easy in a nice and entertaining way, rather than relying on the overworked stuff. Everything was fresh, everything was consistent, everything was justifiable (actually didn't even need justification), and everything was entertaining.

So, yeah, it was easy. But it was elegant.

70A alone was worth the price of admission.

Social Security is anything but a free handout. I've been paying for my retirement ever since I entered the work force. I've also been saving privately (in 401(k), IRA and regular savings). Returns on my investment in Social Security will be an important component of my retirement income.

Describing Social Security as a "government handout" is a serious misstatement of fact.

America doesn't have extended "peasant families", hasn't had since WWII when families fractured - some to fight, others to work in the shipyards. The shift in population during WWII continued the first major shift during the Depression. We have had big agribusiness running farms for decades now. As I understand it, rural Chinese are trying to get to the big urban areas in search of paying jobs. How pathetic that you use an elderly couple waiting for a son to send money home, because there is no safety net, or government programs for the elderly in China.

I visited China and I did not see or meet any extended families among the friends in the cities visited. Perhaps in the rural areas, or mountains? Given the poverty in those areas, the move to the cities is growing. And, the congestion and air pollution in Beijing and Shanghai will continue to kill people until China recognizes the benefits of clean air (and water). Taxes pay for clean air and water, and public services, and safety nets for the poor. You hold China as advanced because it provides none of the above? I met too many Chinese who would love to have what Americans take for granted. Romney/Ryan will be soundly defeated.

I get your sarcasm, and I don't wholeheartedly disagree.

But please understand that the conservative argument concerning social programs isn't about depriving people, it's about making sure that the people who need the help get it efficiently.

Both Medicare & Social Security are as 'socialist' as any other insurance policy. A large number of people pay in & can benefit at a later date. Unless of course someone forgets that the funds are mismanaged or misspent on wars, etc.

Calls to break up or privatize either, when examined closely, are intended to send the funds into the 'free market' to be preyed upon by the unscrupulous cronies that buy Senators & Congressmen.

As for Welfare, there is more than enough money in this country, if managed properly, to support an economic 'safety net' for the needy. I hope you are never in that place.

The Elderly, as you put it, have all paid for the annuity that Social Security is meant to be. So I guess your suggesting that they should 'get stiffed' on the deal that they bought into. Same goes for Medicare. Your suggestion speaks volumes.

After the loss of Billions in pension funds caused by an unregulated/unenforced financial industry these programs will help many recent & soon to be retirees.

While I would have taken Former Secretary of State Condaleeza Rice first and General David Patreus second, both of these choices would have made Governer Romney look like a small, feeble man on the national and world stage, particularly Rice.

At the same time, this country desperately needs someone to look at the books. Keynesian economics is an outright failure and a road to ruin. It's a description of what can happen, not a roadmap for sustained economic prosperity. President Obama is an extremely well educated man, but an economist or businessman he is not; and neither is most of the 'party' that supports him.

I'm not claiming that Mitt Romney is the answer to our prayers, either. He really is economically liberal even if he is a successful businessman, and he turns most actual conservatives' stomachs, including this one. I'm not even sure where Representative Paul Ryan purports to stand, except that he comes from a state that has made tremendous gains towards the fiscal responsibility that our nation so desperately needs, and has espoused those ideals during his public service.

As it stands, I'm not overly confident that Team Mitt can effectively challenge The Dream Team for office. I just have to hope that this race is so grueling, so taxing on the participants, that whoever gets to stay in DC is ready to face the challenge of putting this nation back together!

Our friend from Germany seems to have an interesting perspective on how a civilization "rises" and become "successful". Yes, the USA has had it's share of of wealthy individuals whose drive and ambition have contributed to the overall wealth of the nation and the well being of it's citizens. But I doubt a world lacking the wealth of the USA would be a barter economy. The world was not entirely a barter economy before the 18th century. The issue at hand is balance. If our civilization is to prosper, citizens need to have a reasonable expectation that the rules apply equitably to all. Mr. Freeman is pointing out that Mr. Romney is a glaring example of how our system is out of balance. Human appetites and desires are key drivers to our overall well being, however, when those most powerful, due to their accumulated wealth, rig (buy) the system in a way that skews the outcomes against the majority, eventually there will be a very uncivil outcome. Most US citizens remain ignorant of just how far out of balance the system has gotten. Those in the Tea Party have a sense of it but they have been slyly co-opted by the wealthy to focus their energy on tearing down the meager barriers that prevent the very wealthy from taking even more control. If the "truth" about Romney's wealth is revealed, will citizens will be repelled by the revelation? Will we even get a chance to find out?

I certainly hope that Willard takes Mr. Rove's advice and talks about his wealth both at the convention and at every stop he makes. "I'll bet you a $100G" (or whatever that figure was), "My wife has a couple of caddies" (and I've got the elevator...), "I only made about $350G" (from speaking fees).  Combine that with Bane, with $27million in investment income, with his undisclosed tax returns, etc., etc. and you've got the very model of a modern major plutocrat.  So keep on talking, Willard.  We want to hear all about your very good- and very large- fortune even as you make further plans to increase it at the expense of us proles, our parents and our children. And if, by chance, we fail to applaud your next mention of wealth, success and opportunity (for all scions of multi-millionaires), you can blame OUR capaclty for waging class warfare.

Oh yes, I had intended to say something about OVERDOG in my Comment yesterday, but I forgot to do it.
I'm still wondering if OVERDOG is used anywhere else, or if it was just a humorous coinage for purposes of this puzzle.

It suddenly occurred to me right now that maybe I should have looked it up first.

http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/overdog

Well OK, supposedly it has been used since 1938, but I don't think I myself ever heard it before.

I'm kind of glad to learn it's been around that long. I've never heard it used, but perhaps I'll be the first in my circle.

I used to have two dogs, one of whom was totally well-behaved and obedient and devoted to doing what I wanted her to do. The other one, well, wasn't. I used to refer to them as Wonderdog and Underdog.

That was a nice smooth solve, a very timely quote, and apt cluing. (Although I've had about as much Olympics stuff as I can take for now!)

I'd never run across OVERDOG, but it certainly makes sense. I loathe MEDAL used as a verb--and I've pretty much OD'd on it despite my best efforts recently--but it's certainly appropriate in context of this puzzle.

I had BENCHMARK instead of YARDSTICK for the longest time, and could barely bring myself to enter TEBOWING. I find ECDYSIAST infinitely more acceptable! And I'm really proud of myself for remembering RUFFIAN. She was quite wonderful.

All in all, a most pleasurable outing. Thanks for the fun.

Was it not enough to let Romney first clear up the pile of huge mess created by his own confused and inconsistent public rhetoric, that he has been burdened with new campaign baggage, he was perhaps never prepared for?
My guess is he would have chosen Cantor- but a Mormon and a Jew on the same GOP ticket?  Horrors!
